question.title: How does "old space" differ from "old generation" in Java?
question.body:
I'm trying to interpret the following output of the jstat command:

$ jstat -gcoldcapacity 57208
   OGCMN        OGCMX         OGC           OC       YGC    FGC    FGCT     CGC    CGCT       GCT   
         0.0    1048576.0     717824.0     717824.0    833     6     3.601   387    44.317    93.700

Per documentation:

  • OGC: Current old generation capacity (KB).
  • OC: Current old space capacity (KB).

I have a reasonable understading of generations, and "old generation" are objects surviving a few GC cycles, that are not supposed to be marked until full GC.

What is "old space" then? How is it different from "old generation"?

In my experiments with default settings on OpenJDK 21 they always have the same value.

question_comments.body: The jstat tool squeezes the artifacts of entirely different garbage collection algorithms into the same set of categories. It’s indeed possible that there’s no difference in your environment. For example, there used to be a PermGen in older GC implementations which might have been added to one of those numbers.
